TextEquiv.Unicode: other oblations or holy revenves, shall
be as acceptable unto him, as their sa
crifice that offer any thing out of their
owne chest, store, or possessions. Truly
if a labourer doe offer unto God any
thing of his hire or wages (that is to
say)ifhe give unto the poore, doth it not
seeme a verie acceptable sacrifice unto
God: Very acceptable then is ye almes
that the minister of the church doth be
stowe, proceeding of the wages of the
holy ministerie. Put the case a labo
rer in building a church, receiveth his
wages of ye church goods, should a man
therfore say that the labourer tooke an
almes and y one almes ought not to be
given out of an other? He received wa
ges for his worke. For hee did labour,
Therefore he giveth almes of his wa
ges & of his own, lawful & proper goods.
Therefore then should the minister of
the church seeme to live by almes, and y
he ought not to give almes of almes,
who notwithstanding doth labour for
his wages, & therfore receiveth the re
ward of his worke as a labourer doth,
unto whom the Lord himselfe compa
reth the minister: If any man be so far
past honestie to thinke so, he shal heare
not what I say, but what Paul the A
postle sayth. lf we sowe unto you spiri
tuall thinges, is it a great matter if we
mowe your carnal things: And againe,
Such elders as governe well, are wor
thie of double honor, and chiefly that
travell in preaching and teaching. For
the Scripture sayeth, Thou shalt not
mousell the mouth of the Oze trea
ding out the corne. And The labou
rer is worthie of his hire. Beholde
therefore, the Apostle doth not thinke ye
that inestimable goodnesse of the mi
nisterie can by any meanes be recom
pensed with a vile thing, I mean with
earthly wages. Againe, They that la
boyr, saieth he: They that labour say

other oblations or holy revenves, shall be as acceptable unto him, as their sa crifice that offer any thing out of their owne chest, store, or possessions. Truly if a labourer doe offer unto God any thing of his hire or wages (that is to say)ifhe give unto the poore, doth it not seeme a verie acceptable sacrifice unto God: Very acceptable then is ye almes that the minister of the church doth be stowe, proceeding of the wages of the holy ministerie. Put the case a labo rer in building a church, receiveth his wages of ye church goods, should a man therfore say that the labourer tooke an almes and y one almes ought not to be given out of an other? He received wa ges for his worke. For hee did labour, Therefore he giveth almes of his wa ges & of his own, lawful & proper goods. Therefore then should the minister of the church seeme to live by almes, and y he ought not to give almes of almes, who notwithstanding doth labour for his wages, & therfore receiveth the re ward of his worke as a labourer doth, unto whom the Lord himselfe compa reth the minister: If any man be so far past honestie to thinke so, he shal heare not what I say, but what Paul the A postle sayth. lf we sowe unto you spiri tuall thinges, is it a great matter if we mowe your carnal things: And againe, Such elders as governe well, are wor thie of double honor, and chiefly that travell in preaching and teaching. For the Scripture sayeth, Thou shalt not mousell the mouth of the Oze trea ding out the corne. And The labou rer is worthie of his hire. Beholde therefore, the Apostle doth not thinke ye that inestimable goodnesse of the mi nisterie can by any meanes be recom pensed with a vile thing, I mean with earthly wages. Againe, They that la boyr, saieth he: They that labour say
I, not they saith he, that loyter in tea
thing. These doeth hee compare unto
an ore that is a toyling beast, and a
thresher out of corne, & also to a labou
ring man. That whereof I do so greatly
warne you, is, that because in this our
wicked & unthankefull world, certaine
men, nay rather monsters most un
thankfull are to be found out, that are
perswaded, that ministers do nothing
at all, yea, even such as most faithfully
doe their duetie. For they cry out say
ing, They eate their bread as beggers
doe, and it costeth them nought. By
which name and infamie they terrifie
nity, so that they utterly abhor the mi
nistery, as it were a thing most begger
ly & unhonest. For in such fort the di
abusing, or rather fitlie using to his
purpose our ingratitude & malice. But
why do they not suffer them selves to
be numbred with Christ & the holy A
postles, who were fed & maintained by
many fine wits, and make them to for
sake the studie of good learning & divi
the churches stipend, then to be recko
ned up among those unthakful & proud
people, who have scraped and gathered
vel can devise to enlarge his kingdom,
all their goods together for the most
part, by usury & other wicked means: or
at ye least if they have not gotten their
goods by sinister meanes, they have re
ceived them through the liberalitie &
meere goodnesse of God, for the which
they never sweate or tooke paines:
S. Paule prooveth by strong and
many arguments the right to receive
a stipend for the holy ministerie. Have
we not (saieth he) polver and auto
ritie to eate and drinke, or may we
not carrie about with us a woman
sister: for he meaneth the lawfulnesse
and authoritie to receive anie thing
necessarie for him elfe, his wife, and
his whole housholde. And for that

I, not they saith he, that loyter in tea thing. These doeth hee compare unto an ore that is a toyling beast, and a thresher out of corne, & also to a labou ring man. That whereof I do so greatly warne you, is, that because in this our wicked & unthankefull world, certaine men, nay rather monsters most un thankfull are to be found out, that are perswaded, that ministers do nothing at all, yea, even such as most faithfully doe their duetie. For they cry out say ing, They eate their bread as beggers doe, and it costeth them nought. By which name and infamie they terrifie nity, so that they utterly abhor the mi nistery, as it were a thing most begger ly & unhonest. For in such fort the di abusing, or rather fitlie using to his purpose our ingratitude & malice. But why do they not suffer them selves to be numbred with Christ & the holy A postles, who were fed & maintained by many fine wits, and make them to for sake the studie of good learning & divi the churches stipend, then to be recko ned up among those unthakful & proud people, who have scraped and gathered vel can devise to enlarge his kingdom, all their goods together for the most part, by usury & other wicked means: or at ye least if they have not gotten their goods by sinister meanes, they have re ceived them through the liberalitie & meere goodnesse of God, for the which they never sweate or tooke paines: S. Paule prooveth by strong and many arguments the right to receive a stipend for the holy ministerie. Have we not (saieth he) polver and auto ritie to eate and drinke, or may we not carrie about with us a woman sister: for he meaneth the lawfulnesse and authoritie to receive anie thing necessarie for him elfe, his wife, and his whole housholde.
